title-group.article-title: Evaluating the Performance of the Protective Put Strategy

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1993 The Association for Investment Management and Research (AIMR)

abstract.p: Buying a put option to protect a long stock position is a standard option trade whose payoff pattern is well known. But option strategies in practice often involve a sequence of short-maturity options that must be rolled over as they expire. The payoff pattern of a rollover strategy is hard to evaluate because it depends on the price path of the underlying stock. A simulation approach is used to examine the performance of several types of protective put strategies with short-maturity options. Some seemingly reasonable strategies turn out to provide very little protection, while strategies that involve buying in-the-money options can produce attractive return profiles. Changing the frequency of rollover does not affect performance dramatically. When the market is expected to earn less than the riskless asset, it may be better to liquidate a stock position than to protect it by buying puts.
